;;2023-09-20T18:00:25Z;
;
;;Teresa Ribera
;

;最新一波自然灾害 – 来自 ;洪水利比亚;、希腊和西班牙致;夏威夷和加拿大的野火; - 西班牙环境部长表示，进一步强调了早期预警系统的必要性，以帮助世界应对气候紧急情况的现实。

;

;接受《卫报》采访当她准备前往纽约参加联合国气候雄心峰会和;签署一项具有里程碑意义的条约来保护公海;，特雷莎·里贝拉表示，灾难暴露了地球面临的挑战。

;

;里贝拉还担任西班牙社会党领导的看守政府的副首相，他敦促出席峰会的人们留意联合国秘书长的呼吁，即在未来四年内在世界各地建立拯救生命的早期预警系统。 .

;

;鉴于世界上 95% 的人口可以使用移动宽带网络，并且近 75% 的人口拥有移动电话，专家表示，利用蜂窝网络对即将发生的灾难发出早期预警，有可能挽救生命。生命并显着减少损害。

;

;A ;联合国去年的报告;发现，具有“实质性到全面预警覆盖”的国家的灾害死亡率比覆盖范围有限的国家低八倍。

;

;A ;来自全球适应中心的2019年报告;找到只需 24 小时发出风暴或热浪通知即可将损失减少 30%，而在发展中国家花费 8 亿美元（6.45 亿英镑）购买此类系统每年可避免 30 亿至 160 亿美元的损失。

; < p>;里贝拉说：“[The]承诺;2027 年之前每个国家/地区的预警系统; 是我们之后的关键我们在世界许多地方都看到过这种情况，甚至在制度发展水平较高的富裕国家，例如美国、夏威夷或 ;加拿大，城市不得不疏散;。”

;

;“或者看看;希腊最近发生了什么;，或;最近的联合国报告;发现，由于全球温室气体排放最晚必须在2025年达到峰值，然后迅速减少，以将气温上升限制在1.5摄氏度，因此政府有一个“迅速缩小的窗口”，可以更快地采取行动高于工业化前水平。但;排放量仍在上升;。; p>;

;“我认为我们已经掌握的信息证实我们没有走上实现巴黎目标的轨道，”部长说。 “我认为这意味着我们有三种选择。一是说，‘我们没有走上正轨。句号'。我们不需要召开会议或多边程序来得出这一结论。

;

;“第二种选择是危险的，那就是问谁负责以及原因。当然，我们需要承担责任——全世界实际上应该在减少排放、提供资金、协调一致的政策以及区域和次区域合作方面做更多的事情。”

;

;里贝拉表示，这是一场指责游戏，各国可以选择联合采取有意义的行动，以尽快实现《巴黎协定》的目标。 “我们不需要震耳欲聋的噪音；我们需要一首精心编排的交响乐，将所有部分组合在一起，并让它们朝着同一个方向前进。”她说。

;

;里贝拉称赞公海条约是国际社会可以就有关问题达成历史性协议的证据。看似棘手的问题。

;

;“我认为我们在这方面已经努力了 20 多年，这一事实表明这一切是多么困难，”她说。 “这是国际社会的一项承诺，旨在避免海洋生物多样性遭到破坏，这对于生态系统服务以及我们尚不了解的事物至关重要，因为海洋仍然是一个巨大的未知数。”

;

;她补充道：“这可能是自《巴黎协定》以来最重要的全球条约正在联合国总部签署，这非常具有象征意义。我们再次看到与全球资产（在本例中为海洋）相关的问题如何成为帮助国际社会进步的动力。”

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 02:22:01 +0800 George RR Martin and John Grisham among group of authors suing OpenAIhttps://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/sep/20/authors-lawsuit-openai-george-rr-martin-john-grisham
;;2023-09-20T18:01:20Z;
;
;;George RR Martin
;

;John Grisham、Jodi Picoult 和 George RR Martin 是起诉的 17 位作者之一OpenAI 的“大规模系统性盗窃”是作者对;人工智能;程序提起的一系列法律诉讼中的最新一起未经许可使用其受版权保护的作品。

;
;

;;相关：;;在人工智能问题出现后，亚马逊限制作者每天自行出版超过三本书;

;
;

;在周二向纽约联邦法院提交的文件中，作者指控“对原告注册版权的公然且有害的侵犯”，并称 ChatGPT 计划是一个“大型商业企业”，依赖于“大规模的系统性盗窃”。

;

;该诉讼由作家协会组织，成员包括 David Baldacci、Sylvia Day、Jonathan Franzen 和 Elin Hilderbrand 等人。

;

;“我们必须阻止这种盗窃行为，否则我们将摧毁我们令人难以置信的文学文化，这种文化为美国许多其他创意产业提供了动力，”作家协会首席执行官玛丽·拉森伯格在一份声明中表示。 “伟大的书籍通常是由那些用自己的职业生涯乃至一生的时间来学习和完善自己的技艺的人写成的。为了保护我们的文献，作​​者必须有能力控制他们的作品是否以及如何被生成人工智能使用。”

;

;该诉讼引用了针对每位作者的特定 ChatGPT 搜索，例如指控该程序的 Martin 的搜索为《权力的游戏》的前传制作了“侵权的、未经授权的详细大纲”，该前传的标题为《冰原狼的黎明》，并使用了“马丁在《冰与火之歌》系列中现有书籍中的相同角色”。

;

;OpenAI 的新闻办公室没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;本月早些时候，包括 Michael Chabon 和 David Henry Hwang 在内的几位作者在旧金山起诉 OpenAI，理由是“明显侵犯了

;

;8 月，OpenAI 请求加利福尼亚州的一名联邦法官驳回两起类似的诉讼，其中一项涉及喜剧演员莎拉·西尔弗曼 (Sarah Silverman)，另一项涉及作家保罗·特伦布莱 (Paul Tremblay)。 OpenAI 在一份法庭文件中表示，这些主张“误解了版权的范围，没有考虑到限制和例外（包括合理使用），从而为诸如目前处于人工智能前沿的大型语言模型等创新留下了适当的空间”。

;

;作者对人工智能的反对促使美国最大的图书零售商亚马逊改变了其电子书政策。这家在线巨头现在要求想要通过其 Kindle Direct 计划出版的作家提前通知亚马逊，他们将包含人工智能生成的材料。亚马逊还限制作者每天在 Kindle Direct 上只能购买三本自行出版的新书，以限制人工智能文本的扩散。

;

;;一名骑自行车的人经过华盛顿特区的美联储大楼。
;

;美联储宣布周三将基准利率维持在 22 年高点不变，但暗示可能会再次加息以降低通胀。

;

;在为期两天的会议后，美联储宣布联邦基金利率将维持在 5.25% 至 5.5% 的范围内——与央行;宣布的水平相同; 上次加息是在 7 月份。

;

;这一决定标志着美联储今年第二次在评估之前加息对通胀和整体经济的影响时维持利率不变。 .

;

;美联储一直在以 20 世纪 80 年代以来最快的速度加息，试图降低美国通胀。自 2022 年 3 月以来，利率已从接近于零的水平上涨了 11 倍。

;

;在新冠疫情封锁结束后飙升的通货膨胀率已从去年 6 月的年率 9.1% 大幅下降至 3.7%。但通胀率仍远高于美联储2%的通胀目标，并且有令人担忧的迹象表明美国的物价可能再次上涨。

;

;在沙特供应削减的推动下，油价一直在上涨阿拉伯和俄罗斯。布伦特原油基准价格目前已接近每桶100美元，对央行抗击通胀提出了新的挑战。

;

;8月，美国;通胀年率上升至3.7%，为6月22日以来首次上升，其中能源价格上涨占大部分增加。包括天然气和石油在内的能源大宗商品价格上个月上涨了 10.5%。

;

;美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔多次表示，央行将把利率维持在当前水平或提高利率，直至出现通胀。已得到控制。

;

;上个月在杰克逊霍尔央行行长会议上发表讲话时，;鲍威尔表示;美联储将“谨慎行事”，但会“坚持下去，直到工作完成”。

;

;“我们准备在适当的情况下进一步加息，并打算将政策保持在限制性水平，直到我们有信心通胀持续下降以​​实现我们的目标。”他说。

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 02:22:01 +0800 Brain circuit behind release of breast milk at baby’s cries uncoveredhttps://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2023/sep/20/brain-circuit-behind-breast-milk-release-baby-cries-uncovered
;;2023-09-20T16:33:41Z;
;
;;妇女母乳喂养婴儿
;

;触发新生儿哭声的大脑回路科学家们发现了母亲释放母乳的过程。

;

;这项针对小鼠的研究为怀孕和生育期间大脑发生的复杂变化提供了新的见解。研究发现，幼鼠持续哭泣 30 秒会触发催产素的释放，催产素是一种控制母亲母乳释放反应的大脑化学物质。

;

;“我们的研究结果揭示了哭泣的婴儿如何启动母亲的大脑纽约大学兰格尼健康中心的研究生、该研究的合著者哈本·伊萨 (Habon Issa) 说：“让她的身体做好接受护理的准备。” “如果没有这样的准备，吸吮和泌乳之间可能会有几分钟的延迟，这可能会导致婴儿沮丧和父母压力。”

;

;研究表明，一旦提示，激素激增会持续持续很长时间。大约五分钟后逐渐减少，使小鼠母亲能够喂养幼崽，直到它们吃饱或再次开始哭泣。

;

;当母亲听到婴儿哭闹时，乳房会漏奶的观察结果并不新鲜。但最新的研究首次确定了科学家所描述的“从哭到牛奶的管道”背后的大脑机制，并可能为更好地理解;许多女性都进行母乳喂养;。

;

;调查结果，;发表在 Nature; 上，表明当幼鼠开始哭泣时，声音信息会传输到其母亲大脑中称为丘脑后层内核 (PIL) 的区域。然后，这个感觉中枢将信号发送到另一个称为下丘脑的区域中释放催产素的脑细胞（神经元）。

;

;大多数时候，这些下丘脑神经元被“锁定”，以防止误报和浪费牛奶。然而，连续哭泣 30 秒后，来自 PIL 的信号逐渐增强，并压倒了内置的抑制机制，引发催产素释放。

;

;“这就像大脑想要确保婴儿确实存在一样纽约大学朗格尼分校的罗伯特·弗罗姆克教授和合著者罗伯特·弗罗姆克教授说： “有特定的大脑回路会阻碍这个过程。一旦确信那里确实有一个婴儿，就会释放刹车。”

;

;Froemke 说，这些发现为科学家们提供了这个过程如何在人类身上发挥作用的路线图。 “老鼠妈妈与人类妈妈不同，但从广义上讲，我们认为它是相似的，”他说。 “这真是令人困惑。我们可以在火星上放置一个机器人，但我们并不了解如何喂养孩子和母乳喂养的基本知识。”

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 01:52:02 +0800 Egon Schiele art to be returned to heirs of Jewish cabaret star killed by Nazishttps://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2023/sep/20/egon-schiele-works-to-be-returned-to-heirs-of-jewish-cabaret-star-killed-by-nazis
;;2023-09-20T16:50:43Z;
;
;;Grünbaum 用手托着下巴，凝视着镜头
;

;Egon 的七件作品曼哈顿检察官宣布，在美国关押的席勒作品将被交还给一位犹太歌舞表演明星的继承人，这些明星在达豪集中营被杀之前拥有这些作品，这标志着艺术界持续时间最长的归还案件之一的转折点。纳粹时代被掠夺的艺术品。

;

;这位奥地利表现主义者的作品，包括一幅自画像，计划于周三在曼哈顿地区检察官办公室举行的仪式上自愿归还给弗里茨·格伦鲍姆的继承人，据《纽约时报》报道。

;

;这些作品每件价值 78 万美元至 275 万美元（63 万英镑至 220 万英镑），此前由现代艺术博物馆和摩根图书馆与图书馆收藏。纽约博物馆、加利福尼亚州圣巴巴拉艺术博物馆以及两位私人收藏家，世界犹太人大会主席塞尔日·萨巴尔斯基 (Serge Sabarsky) 和罗纳德·S·劳德 (Ronald S. Lauder)。

;

;其中包括水彩画和铅笔作品《妓女》（1912 年）、纸上铅笔画《艺术家妻子伊迪丝肖像》（1915 年）和《自画像》（1910 年），以黑色粉笔和水彩画于棕色纸上。

;

;Grünbaum，一口井- 著名的奥地利漫画家和歌曲作家，在第二次世界大战开始前的几年里积累了近 450 部作品。这些藏品主要由奥地利战前蓬勃发展的现代主义运动的作品组成，其中包括古斯塔夫·克里姆特 (Gustav Klimt) 的门生席勒 (Schiele) 的 81 件艺术作品。

;

;格伦鲍姆 (Grünbaum) 于 1938 年 5 月在家乡维也纳被纳粹逮捕。 1941 年 1 月死于达豪集中营。他在纳粹时期的艺术收藏品的具体去向尚不清楚，但他大约四分之一的作品在 20 世纪 50 年代通过瑞士艺术品经销商进入了国际市场。

;

;二十多年来，格伦鲍姆的继承人一直试图收回他收藏的作品。 1998年，席勒的画作《沃利肖像》和《死城》成为奥地利和美国之间外交争端的主题，因为它们被借给现代艺术博物馆，然后因传票而被保存在纽约。这些作品后来被归还。

;

;Grünbaum 的继承人试图通过法律强制归还奥地利阿尔贝蒂娜博物馆和利奥波德博物馆收藏的 12 件席勒作品，但政府委员会在 2010 年和 2015 年拒绝了归还要求，认为这些作品从未被归还。被纳粹政权没收，但被他自己的亲戚卖掉。

;

;事实证明，美国的一项法律挑战更为成功，曼哈顿的一名法官于 2015 年做出了有利于继承人的裁决，他们说他们有证据证明格伦鲍姆被迫签署一份文件，放弃他的珍贵收藏。去年五月，针对该裁决的上诉被驳回。

;
;

;;相关：;;从美国博物馆查获的据信在大屠杀期间被盗的席勒艺术品;

;
;

;上周纽约调查人员从芝加哥艺术学院、匹兹堡卡内基博物馆和俄亥俄州欧柏林学院艾伦纪念艺术博物馆查获了三件席勒作品。

;

;欧柏林在一份声明中表示，正在与调查人员合作，并有信心学院于 1958 年“合法获得”了《黑发女孩》的作品，并且“我们合法拥有它”。

;

;曼哈顿的裁决预计不会对继承人对两人提出的法律挑战产生直接影响奥地利博物馆。

;

;美国 1976 年《外国主权豁免法》普遍禁止外国及其机构在美国法院受到起诉，尽管该法对涉及“违反《外国主权法》和《外国主权豁免法》的规定而征用财产的诉讼规定了“征用例外”。国际法”。

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 01:22:01 +0800 King Charles lights flame at Paris’s Arc de Triomphe for start of three-day visithttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/sep/20/king-charles-lights-flame-at-pariss-arc-de-triomphe-for-start-of-three-day-visit
;;2023-09-20T15:49:54Z;
;
;;查理三世国王和卡米拉王后与埃马纽埃尔·马克龙在巴黎。
;

;查尔斯国王点燃了火焰在巴黎凯旋门的无名战士墓前，与埃马纽埃尔·马克龙一起沿着香榭丽舍大街开始;为期三天的国事访问;。

;

;在凯旋门，74 45岁的国王和45岁的总统在明年诺曼底登陆80周年之前纪念了英国和法国的共同牺牲和持续的军事合作。这是友谊展示的一部分，旨在展示 ;英法关系;在英国脱欧后的鲍里斯·约翰逊执政期间信任几乎完全崩溃。

;

;国王访问的核心内容是周三晚上在伦敦举行的豪华国宴。凡尔赛宫的镜厅，这是著名的 17 世纪画廊，由“太阳王”路易十四建造，旨在彰显法国君主政体的权力和威严。

;

;周三上午，一支团队在凡尔赛宫使用卷尺将一张 60 多米长的大桌子的座位设置最终确定为毫米，以便在“国王的餐桌”上容纳 150 至 160 名客人。

;

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 00:22:02 +0800 UN inquiry into rights in Iran urged to look at detention of dual nationalshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/20/un-inquiry-into-rights-in-iran-urged-to-look-at-detention-of-dual-nationals
;;2023-09-20T15:29:43Z;
;
;;People disembark from a plane
;

;A UN inquiry into human rights in Iran has been asked to intervene in the growing detention of Iranian dual nationals and to identify the practice as unlawful state hostage-taking.

;

;The inquiry, set up last November by the UN human rights council and being overseen by three lawyers, is due to report in March 2024. A submission from the Free Nazanin campaign, which worked for the release of the British-Iranian dual national Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, warns the UN body that Iran is normalising the capture of dual nationals for use as diplomatic bargaining chips .

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Nightmare is finally over': Americans freed from Iran speak of relief on return to US;

;
;

;The submission says it has become an integral part of Iran's abuse of human rights in the country. Iran has largely claimed the detainees are spies.

;

;Richard Ratcliffe, Nazanin's husband, said: “We still look at these cases as individual stories, and individual transactions, and argue about which political leader would have handled it best. We are not yet looking at it as a transnational system of organised crime. It is a business that costs far too little at present, and is unravelling many other human rights.”

;

;He stressed he was delighted that ;five Americans had been released; by Iran this week as part of a complex wider deal. But he said: “It is really hard for those the US government left behind and still in harm's way. It will be essential while the Iranian president, Ebrahim Raisi, is still in New York that the US government gets assurances from him that those left behind are kept safe, if it hasn't already got them, and that there are no more executions of foreign nationals for leverage.”

;

;He added: “The bigger picture is that the world needs to take its head out of the sand. For too long, western governments have been reluctant to acknowledge Iran's hostage diplomacy, and talk instead of consular cases. Iran's hostage enterprise has expanded and morphed into something more dangerous because it has been allowed to.”

;

;The exact number of dual nationals held in Iranian jails, mainly on spying charges, is unknown but the campaign estimates it is more than 30.

;

;In the submission, the campaign says: “Iran's hostage-taking has escalated in 2022, particularly after the nationwide protests that erupted in September 2022, leading to a significant increase in human rights violations committed against foreign and dual nationals, both in terms of scale and severity. This escalation has involved an alarming increase in executions of dual nationals for leverage over foreign states.”

;

;Calling for a more coherent international response, it says: “Secret negotiations and prisoner swaps risk paving the way for a policy of appeasement that emboldens Iran to continue to commit hostage-taking and other crimes in exchange for political leverage. They also serve to distract attention from the significant human rights violations committed by the Iranian regime and portray Iran's hostage-taking as an isolated bilateral issue, rather than an institutionalised practice of blackmailing that threatens international peace and security.”

;

;It says Iran is setting a “terrifying precedent” that could be replicated around the world by threatening to execute prisoners in return for concessions. It claims: “Iran is therefore gradually adopting an execution diplomacy, whereby the Iranian regime is executing or credibly threatening to execute dual nationals as a warning sign to intimidate dissidents and pressure western governments into succumbing to its demands. This deeply alarming type of diplomacy is seemingly being spearheaded by Iran.”

;

;The group claims there is evidence that in attempts to abduct individuals from Europe, the Iranian intelligence services have begun developing closer relationships with organised criminal gangs in the UK and across Europe to expand the capability of its networks.

;

;Accusing Iran of being involved in state-sponsored brutality unprecedented in modern statecraft, the report goes on to identify some Iranian officials that it regards as integral to the process.

;

;There has always been an ambiguity in nation states and hostage families about the incentive effect of striking deals. Many governments abhor these deals in public but then quietly strike an agreement in order to secure a citizen's release.

;

;Siamak Namazi, one of the five Americans released as part of the recently announced US-Iran prisoner exchange, said: “It is only if the free world finally agrees to collectively impose draconian consequences on those who use human lives as mere bargaining chips that the Iranian regime and its ilk will be compelled to make difference choices.”

;

;On the day of the hostages' release, the US censured Iran's intelligence and security ministry for its involvement in the wrongful detention of US citizens, and the former president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad for his support of the ministry.

;

;The US defended the deal for the five on the basis that the $6bn released to Iran was Iranian money, and use of the cash in Iranian banks in Qatar would be monitored to ensure it was spent only for humanitarian purposes.

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 23:52:02 +0800 Ultra-processed food linked to higher risk of depression, research findshttps://www.theguardian.com/food/2023/sep/20/ultra-processed-food-linked-higher-risk-depression-research-finds
;;2023-09-20T15:17:27Z;
;
;;Bottles of Coca-cola products, including Diet Coke, on a store shelf on July 14, 2023 in New York City.
;

;Consuming large amounts of ultra-processed food, especially drinks containing artificial sweeteners, is associated with a higher risk of depression, ;research; has found.

;

;Despite extensive data linking ultra-processed food with ;physical ill health;, such as strokes, heart attacks and raised blood pressure, this is the first large study to suggest that consuming ultra-processed foods and drinks, particularly those that include artificial sweeteners, could increase the instance of depression.

;

;Using data from one of ;the biggest studies of women's long-term health in the US;, researchers at Massachusetts general hospital and Harvard medical school examined the diets and mental health of more than 30,000 primarily white middle-aged women between 2003 and 2017 who did not already have depression.

;

;The authors estimated the overall extent of ultra-processed food intake as well as the type of food, such as ultra-processed grain foods, sweet snacks, ready-to-eat meals, fats and sauces, ultra-processed dairy products, savoury snacks, processed meat, beverages and artificial sweeteners.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Ultra-processed foods: the 19 things everyone needs to know;

;
;

;They then compared how many women went on to develop depression against their consumption of ultra-processed food. Adjusting for other health, lifestyle and socioeconomic risk factors for depression, the research, published in US journal JAMA Network Open, found that those who consumed nine portions or more of ultra-processed foods a day had a 49% increased risk of depression compared with those who consumed fewer than four portions a day.

;

;In addition, those who reduced their intake of ultra-processed food by at least three servings a day were at lower risk of depression than those with relatively stable intake.

;

;“These findings suggest that greater ultra-processed foods intake, particularly artificial sweeteners and artificially sweetened beverages, is associated with increased risk of depression,” the authors concluded.

;

;“Experimental studies have shown that artificial sweeteners may trigger the transmission of particular signalling molecules in the brain that are important for mood.”

;

;Responding to the findings, Keith Frayn, emeritus professor of human metabolism at the University of Oxford, said: “The relationship between artificial sweeteners and depression stands out clearly. This adds to growing concerns about artificial sweeteners and cardiometabolic health. The link with depression needs confirmation and further research to suggest how it might be brought about.”

;

;Others urged greater caution. Prof David Curtis, an honorary professor at University College London Genetics Institute, said: “The only foodstuffs which [this study] shows are associated with increased risk of depression are artificial sweeteners. Of course, this does not mean that an effect of artificial sweeteners is to increase depression risk – it is just that people with increased risk of developing depression tend to consume larger quantities of artificial sweeteners.”

;

;But the authors disagree. Prof Andrew T Chan, chief of the clinical and translational epidemiology unit at Massachusetts general hospital and co-author of the research, said: “The strength of our study is that we were able to assess diet several years before the onset of depression. This minimises the likelihood that our findings are simply due to individuals with depression being more likely to choose ultra-processed foods.”

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 23:52:02 +0800 ‘Oldest wooden structure’ discovered on border of Zambia and Tanzaniahttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/sep/20/oldest-wooden-structure-discovered-on-border-of-zambia-and-tanzania
;;2023-09-20T15:00:25Z;
;
;;The excavation team uncovering the wooden structure.
;

;Researchers have discovered remnants of what is thought to be the world's oldest known wooden structure, an arrangement of logs on the bank of a river bordering Zambia and Tanzania that predates the rise of modern humans.

;

;The simple structure, made by shaping two logs with sharp stone tools, may have formed part of a walkway or platform for human ancestors who lived along the Kalambo River nearly 500,000 years ago.

;

;Marks on the logs show they were cut, chopped and scraped with an array of stone tools found at the site. One log, a type of bushwillow, overlies the other and is held in place by a large inverted U-shaped notch in its underside.

; ;

;“When I first saw it, I thought this can't be real. The wood and the stone suggest a high level of ingenuity, technological skill and planning,” said Prof Larry Barham, an archaeologist at the University of Liverpool who led the work.

;

;“It could be part of a walkway or part of a foundation for a platform,” he said. “A platform could be used as a place to store things, to keep firewood or food dry, or it might have been a place to sit and make things. You could put a little shelter on top and sleep there.”

;

;Scientists at the University of Aberystwyth dated the structure to at least 476,000 years old, from long before ;Homo sapiens; are thought to have emerged about 300,000 years ago. The structure may be the work of ;Homo heidelbergensis;, a predecessor of modern humans that lived in the region.

;

;The scientists arrived at Kalambo Falls in 2019 hoping to press on with excavations made in 2006, only to find the river had shifted course and flooded the area.

; ;

;Barham's plan B involved sliding down a 30ft cliff to a strip of beach on the Kalambo River upstream of a 770ft waterfall that plunges towards Lake Tanganyika. There he found the first of the wooden items recovered on the trip, a digging stick dated to about 390,000 years ago.

;

;Other wooden items included a wedge, a split branch with a notch that may have formed part of a trap, and a log cut at both ends. “It might be a work surface, like a Black and Decker workbench,” Barham said of the log.

;

;The findings are remarkable because wood so rarely survives for long periods. The material at Kalambo Falls was preserved by waterlogged sediments that are starved of oxygen.

;

;“It may not be the beginning of the built environment, but it is the earliest time we have of people taking trees, taking charge of this material, and shaping something that has no precedent, that has no natural form to emulate,” Barham said. “It's a real cultural imposition on the landscape.”

;

;The site probably contains more ancient wooden objects, and Barham said the priority was to work with the Zambian government to get Kalambo Falls recognised as a Unesco world heritage site.

;

;Dr Sonia Harmand, an expert in early stone age archaeology at Stony Brook University in New York called it a groundbreaking discovery.

;

;“We know so few things about the use of organic materials during the early stages of our evolution that this makes it a very wanted discovery,” she said. “The team is formed of world experts and no doubt the discovery is solid.”

;

;Dr Annemieke Milks, a Palaeolithic archaeologist at the University of Reading, said the interlocking, shaped logs were evidence of a “behavioural threshold”, showing that as early as 476,000 years ago, humans used large-scale materials to transform their lived environment.

;

;“Although quite simple in nature, the shaped and interlocking logs indicate that these humans structured their environment,” she said. “While many other animals engage in such behaviours, the Kalambo Falls humans made use of multiple materials – at the very least stone and wood, and possibly fire – to do so.

;

;“The rarity of wood preservation implies that such behaviours were more widespread than what we witness in the archaeological record,” she added. “Although the use of wood for tools and structures remains commonplace today, their findings provide a rare glimpse into the role that this simple material played in human evolution.”
